posts.title: Figure skater whose parents died in D.C. plane crash says they changed their flight
top_comments:
A meeting got canceled at my dad's work so he decided to go to the airport and get on standby for an earlier flight. He was flying from London to New York, to join the rest of us who had flown a day earlier to visit family. That was Dec 21, 1988. His original plane was bombed over Lockerbie, Scotland killing 270 people. 

We didn't know he'd gotten the earlier flight. And when he landed in New York 3 hours earlier than expected, he decided to meet up with his best friend rather than go directly to his mom's house where we all were. It wasn't until someone called the best friend to inform him my dad was dead that dad found out about the crash.

Ugh, awful--that's an added level of shit to process on top of a whole lot of already difficult grief and shock that he must be going through. 

I fly a lot for work and tend to change my flights a lot on the fly when new meetings come up or get moved I need to still be able to make. Every time I do I always wonder if it's going to mean I either have changed into a flight that's destined to crash, or changed away from one that was going to crash.

In plane crash stories, there are always some unfortunate incidences of people who changed their flight to be on the plane that crashed or relieving stories where someone changed their flight or missed the flight that crashed. Just the nature of it I suppose
just so sad. I hope he has a strong support system, I can’t imagine how you even begin to process this kind of loss

Back in the late 80s, my father's cousin woke up late and missed his flight, he ended up on Pan Am Flight 103.

My dad's side of the family have all had a thing about being on time ever since.
What's crazy is if they went on it it could of shifted the timing of their flight by a few seconds, enough to not crash.

My uncle had a ticket to fly to Santo Domingo from NYC. About a month before departure, my uncle got into a fight with his friend and changed his stop to Puerta Plata. 

Imagine his horror on November 12th, 2001 when the American Airlines 587 plane that took off in front of him, the one he originally was on, crashed shortly after takeoff due to pilot error. Two months post 9/11 made it all the more heartbreaking and scary.
Every major disaster has stories of people who weren’t going to be there but ended up being there and people who were going to be there but then weren’t.  Plans changing is a fact of life.

I had to google to make sure this was the same Pam  Am flight. My dad was supposed to be on this flight for work as well but got bumped off (never said why) and had to take a later flight. I remember seeing the news that day and my mom freaking out and then getting a call that he was ok.                                             I remember my dad talking about he met some US college kids on the flight there and found out they had the same return flight home. Even though they were strangers my dad always said he never forgot them and it should have been him too.    Weird to see other parents/family on here have a similar experience. Small world.
How is this news? Who gives a fuck?

posts.title: Yale professor who studies fascism fleeing US to work in Canada
top_comments:
"Out here, nobody knows where I am, and I’m believed to be away on a trip. Here are brewing economically and politically dark times, so I’m happy to be able to get away from everything." 

-Einstein hiding in Northern Germany in 1922, eleven years before he renounced his German citizenship following Hitlers rise to chancellor.

A poignant quote from the article:  "Social media posts spread on Wednesday, noting the alarm sounded by a scholar of fascism leaving the country over its political climate. Nikole Hannah-Jones, the journalist and creator of the 1619 Project,[wrote](https://bsky.app/profile/nhannahjones.bsky.social/post/3llakwvszts2c) on the social media platform Bluesky: “When scholars of authoritarianism and fascism leave US universities because of the deteriorating political situation here, we should really worry.”

The vast majority of U.S. residents cannot leave. They either lack the resources or no one would be willing to take them on due to factors such as age, education, and others reasons. Protected is our freedom to travel, and essentially to leave has been our right. However, with a passport costing $250 and roughly 60% of Americans being a single paycheck away from homelessness, the majority have no freedom to travel or leave.  Trickle-down only worked for billionaires. The middle class has been significantly eroded over the past few decades. We are now stuck with our makings.

"Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it"

This is simply an example of the inverse being true.
If only there had been a literal decade of warnings for people to pay attention to…
He'll be back when he has to do his fieldwork.
As a Canadian, I think we're better off for having him. But I'm sorry it's coming to this; I have friends in the States and I really feel for them.

This is one of the few silver linings for Canada - a reverse brain drain.

Still, I'd rather have a sane southern neighbor.
Fleeing from Germany to France vibes.
We're hostages tied to a chair while children with loaded guns are running around.  I hate it here

posts.title: Figure skater whose parents died in D.C. plane crash says they changed their flight
top_comments:
A meeting got canceled at my dad's work so he decided to go to the airport and get on standby for an earlier flight. He was flying from London to New York, to join the rest of us who had flown a day earlier to visit family. That was Dec 21, 1988. His original plane was bombed over Lockerbie, Scotland killing 270 people. 

We didn't know he'd gotten the earlier flight. And when he landed in New York 3 hours earlier than expected, he decided to meet up with his best friend rather than go directly to his mom's house where we all were. It wasn't until someone called the best friend to inform him my dad was dead that dad found out about the crash.

Ugh, awful--that's an added level of shit to process on top of a whole lot of already difficult grief and shock that he must be going through. 

I fly a lot for work and tend to change my flights a lot on the fly when new meetings come up or get moved I need to still be able to make. Every time I do I always wonder if it's going to mean I either have changed into a flight that's destined to crash, or changed away from one that was going to crash.

In plane crash stories, there are always some unfortunate incidences of people who changed their flight to be on the plane that crashed or relieving stories where someone changed their flight or missed the flight that crashed. Just the nature of it I suppose
just so sad. I hope he has a strong support system, I can’t imagine how you even begin to process this kind of loss

Back in the late 80s, my father's cousin woke up late and missed his flight, he ended up on Pan Am Flight 103.

My dad's side of the family have all had a thing about being on time ever since.
What's crazy is if they went on it it could of shifted the timing of their flight by a few seconds, enough to not crash.

My uncle had a ticket to fly to Santo Domingo from NYC. About a month before departure, my uncle got into a fight with his friend and changed his stop to Puerta Plata. 

Imagine his horror on November 12th, 2001 when the American Airlines 587 plane that took off in front of him, the one he originally was on, crashed shortly after takeoff due to pilot error. Two months post 9/11 made it all the more heartbreaking and scary.
Every major disaster has stories of people who weren’t going to be there but ended up being there and people who were going to be there but then weren’t.  Plans changing is a fact of life.

I had to google to make sure this was the same Pam  Am flight. My dad was supposed to be on this flight for work as well but got bumped off (never said why) and had to take a later flight. I remember seeing the news that day and my mom freaking out and then getting a call that he was ok.                                             I remember my dad talking about he met some US college kids on the flight there and found out they had the same return flight home. Even though they were strangers my dad always said he never forgot them and it should have been him too.    Weird to see other parents/family on here have a similar experience. Small world.
How is this news? Who gives a fuck?
